text:
Introduction
Praise be to Allah, Lord of the worlds, and peace and blessings be upon the one whom Allah sent as a mercy to the worlds, Muhammad, the Truthful and Trustworthy, and upon his family, his companions, the followers, and those who follow their path until the Day of Judgment.
As for what follows:
The heart of a Muslim is constantly attached to Allah Almighty in all his sayings, actions, movements, and times of rest. This attachment is coupled with abundant, continuous remembrance (Dhikr), through which this heart attains tranquility and distance from heedlessness and the death of hearts that accompanies it. There is no doubt that every day in the life of a Muslim contains various types of acts of worship and obedience performed in daily life. Among the greatest of those acts of worship that are repeated for the Muslim is the Prayer (Salah), which is the pillar of this great religion and its upright support. Due to its high status and great honor, this Prayer has many Adhkar (remembrances) and supplications: some are before it, some are within it, and some are after it.

book_title: Adhkar of Prayers and What Comes Before and After Them
text:
The more the believer is keen on following and emulating the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) in his prayer, the greater the hope for its acceptance by Allah compared to others, and the greater the reward and recompense attained from the Lord, Glory be to Him. For this reason, and as a benefit and reminder for myself and my Muslim brothers, I have collected what Allah has facilitated for me to collect of the Adhkar reported regarding the prayers, and what is before and after them. I named it "Adhkar of Prayers and What Comes Before and After Them," abbreviating and limiting it to what has been authenticated or classified as Hasan (good) by the scholars, so that it may be easy and accessible for the noble reader. If I have done well, it is from Allah Almighty alone, and if I have erred, it is from myself and Satan, and Allah and His Messenger are innocent of that. I ask Allah to benefit all Muslims with this work, to bring about much good through it, and to make it purely for His Noble Face; indeed, He is the Guardian of that and Capable of it. Praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds.
Written by: Abu Al-Hamza Ahmed bin Muhammad bin Hussein bin Ali Al-Hajjaji
20 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1441 AH

text:
Topic Titles
Topic One: Adhkar reported before the Prayer. This includes Adhkar from the moment of waking from sleep until the completion of the Adhan.
Topic Two: Adhkar reported within the Five Daily Prayers. This includes Adhkar reported from the opening Takbir (Takbirat al-Ihram) until the Tasleem.
Topic Three: Adhkar reported after the Five Daily Prayers. This includes Adhkar reported from after the Tasleem until putting away one's clothes at home.
Topic Four: Adhkar reported in prayers other than the Five Daily Prayers. This includes Adhkar of the Night Prayer, Funeral Prayer, Eid Prayer, Istikhara Prayer, Rain Prayer (Istisqa), and Eclipse Prayer.

• Topic One: Adhkar Reported Before the Prayer
This includes Adhkar from the moment of waking from sleep until the completion of the Adhan.

Adhkar of Waking from Sleep:
First: "Praise be to Allah Who gave us life after He caused us to die, and unto Him is the resurrection." (1)
Second: "Praise be to Allah Who healed me in my body, returned my soul to me, and permitted me to remember Him." (2)

Dhikr upon Entering the Toilet:
"In the name of Allah" (3), "O Allah, I seek refuge with You from male and female devils (Al-Khubuth wa Al-Khaba'ith)." (4)

Dhikr after Completing Wudu:
"I bear witness that there is no god but Allah alone, having no partner, and I bear witness that Muhammad is His servant and messenger. [O Allah, make me of the repentant, and make me of the purified]."
The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said regarding the virtue of this Dhikr that whoever says it: "The eight gates of Paradise will be opened for him, to enter from whichever he wishes." (1)
foot_note: 1. Narrated by Muslim via Uqbah bin Amir Al-Juhani (1/210) number (234), At-Tirmidhi via Umar bin Al-Khattab (1/78) number (55). The portion in brackets is from At-Tirmidhi. Al-Albani said: A (Sahih) Hadith, Al-Jami' As-Saghir (2/1061) number (6167), Sahih At-Targhib (219), Al-Irwa number (96). Some scholars stated that the addition (O Allah, make me of the repentant and make me of the purified) is Shadh (anomalous): Ja'far bin Muhammad bin Imran was unique in reporting it.

Dhikr upon the Muadhin's Testimony:
When the Muadhin says: "I bear witness that there is no god but Allah * I bear witness that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah," the listener says: "And I bear witness, and I bear witness." (1)

Dhikr after the Two Testimonies following the Muadhin's Testimony:
"I bear witness that there is no god but Allah alone, having no partner, and that Muhammad is His servant and messenger. I am pleased with Allah as a Lord, with Muhammad as a Messenger, and with Islam as a religion." (2). The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: Whoever says this supplication, "his sin will be forgiven."

Dhikr immediately after completing the Adhan:
He sends blessings upon the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) by saying: "O Allah, send prayers upon Muhammad and upon the family of Muhammad, as You sent prayers upon Ibrahim and upon the family of Ibrahim; You are indeed Worthy of Praise, Full of Glory. Dhikr after Praying upon the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him):
"O Allah, Lord of this perfect call and the established prayer, grant Muhammad the Wasila (a station in Paradise) and the Virtue, and resurrect him to the Praiseworthy Station which You have promised him." • Topic Two: Adhkar Reported Within the Five Daily Prayers
This includes Adhkar reported from the opening Takbir (Takbirat al-Ihram) until the Tasleem.

Dhikr after Facing the Qiblah and Commencing the Prayer:
"Allah is the Greatest (Allahu Akbar)." (1)

Adhkar Reported after the Opening Takbir (The Opening Supplications - Istiftah):
First Dhikr: "O Allah, distance me from my sins as You have distanced the East from the West. O Allah, cleanse me from my sins as a white garment is cleansed from dirt. O Allah, wash me from my sins with snow, water, and hail." (2). Al-Albani said: "This is said in the obligatory prayers, and it is the most authentic of the opening supplications in terms of chain of transmission." (3)

1. Agreed upon: Al-Bukhari via Abu Hurairah (1/158) number (793), Muslim (1/298) number (397).

text: Second Dhikr: "I have turned my face toward Him Who created the heavens and the earth, inclining toward truth, [submitting], and I am not of the polytheists. Indeed, my prayer, my rites of sacrifice, my living and my dying are for Allah, Lord of the worlds. No partner has He. And this I have been commanded, and I am of the Muslims. O Allah, You are the King, there is no god but You. You are my Lord, and I am Your servant. I have wronged myself and acknowledged my sin, so forgive me all my sins. Indeed, none forgives sins but You. And guide me to the best of morals; none guides to the best of them but You. And turn away from me the evil of them; none turns away from me the evil of them but You. Here I am and at Your service; all good is in Your hands, and evil is not attributed to You. [The guided one is he whom You guide]. I exist by You and return to You. Blessed and Exalted are You. I seek Your forgiveness and repent to You." (1)

Fifth Dhikr: "Praise be to Allah, many, good, blessed praises." A man from the Companions opened with this, so the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said: "I saw twelve angels racing for it, which of them would raise it up." (2)

Dhikr after the Opening Supplication:
Seeking refuge in Allah from the accursed Satan (Isti'adhah), and it has three forms:
First: "I seek refuge in Allah from the accursed Satan." (3)

Dhikr after the Opening Supplication and Seeking Refuge:
He reads Surah Al-Fatiha. This is done in every Rak'ah and in every prayer, whether he is an Imam, a follower, or praying alone; based on the saying of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him): "There is no prayer for the one who does not read the Opening of the Book (Al-Fatiha)." (3)

Dhikr after Reading Al-Fatiha:
"Ameen," whether he is an Imam, a follower, or praying alone. The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said regarding the virtue of Ameen: "Whoever's saying of Ameen coincides with the Ameen of the angels, his past sins will be forgiven." (1) He also said: "So say: Ameen, and Allah will answer you." (2)

Dhikr after saying "Ameen":
He reads whatever is easy from the Quran (3), in the first two Rak'ahs of all five prayers (4), except for the follower (Ma'mum) in audible prayers, who limits himself to Al-Fatiha.

Dhikr for one who experiences whispering (distraction) in Prayer:
"He spits (dryly) (5) to his left three times and seeks refuge in Allah from Satan" (6), meaning he says: "I seek refuge in Allah from the accursed Satan."

He said: "I did that and Allah removed him from me."

Dhikr when moving from one pillar to another in Prayer:
Such as moving from standing to bowing (Ruku), or to prostration (Sujud), or sitting between the two prostrations, or moving from prostration to standing. In all these cases, he says: "Allah is the Greatest (Allahu Akbar)" (1) [Except for rising from bowing, which has a specific Dhikr we will mention in its place]. Since this is a known matter, I did not repeat its mention at Ruku, Sujud, or otherwise.

text:
Adhkar Reported in Ruku (Bowing):
First Dhikr: "Glory be to my Lord, the Magnificent (Subhana Rabbiya Al-Adheem)" (1) three times (2). This is the obligatory Dhikr in Ruku.
Second Dhikr: "Glorified, Holy, Lord of the angels and the Spirit (Subbuhun Quddus, Rabbu Al-Mala'ikati wa Ar-Ruh)" (3).
Third Dhikr: "Glory be to You, O Allah, our Lord, and with Your praise. O Allah, forgive me." (4).
Fourth Dhikr: "Glory be to You and with Your praise, there is no god but You." (5).
Fifth Dhikr: "O Allah, to You I have bowed, in You I have believed, and to You I have submitted. My hearing, my sight, my brain, my bones, and my nerves have humbled themselves to You." (6).

Adhkar upon Rising from Ruku:
These are of two types:
First: Pertains to the Imam and the one praying alone, which is the 'Tasmee', meaning saying: "Allah hears whoever praises Him (Sami'a Allahu liman hamidah)" (1). Then they both add the 'Tahmid' (Praise) after the Tasmee, as this is established from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) (2).
Second: What pertains to the Follower (Ma'mum), which is the 'Tahmid' (3).
For the Tahmid, there are four wordings:
First: "Our Lord, to You is praise (Rabbana laka al-hamd)." (4)
Second: "Our Lord, and to You is praise (Rabbana wa laka al-hamd)." (5)

I bear witness that there is no god but Allah, and I bear witness that Muhammad is the Messenger of Allah." (2).

1. Narrated by Muslim from Ibn Al-Zubayr (1/415) No. (594).
2. Majmu' Fatawa wa Rasa'il Al-Uthaymin (13/253).

book_title: Remembrances of Prayers: Before and After
text: like the foam of the sea (1)" (2). And the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said regarding the merit of this remembrance when he guided the Companions to it: "Shall I not teach you something by which you will catch up with those who preceded you and surpass those who come after you, and no one will be better than you except one who does the like of what you did...?" (3) So he mentioned it to them. He also said: "Successive [words], the sayer—or doer—of which will not be disappointed after every written prayer" (4). Second Formula: "Glory be to Allah (*Subhan Allah*) twenty-five times, Praise be to Allah (*Alhamdulillah*) twenty-five times, Allah is the Greatest (*Allahu Akbar*) twenty-five times, and There is no god but Allah (*La ilaha illa Allah*) twenty-five times" (5).
foot_note:
1. (Even if they were like the foam of the sea): Meaning in abundance and magnitude like the foam of the sea: which is what rises upon its surface when it is agitated and wavy. [Commentary by Muhammad Abd al-Baqi] on Muslim (1/418).
2. Narrated by Muslim from Abu Hurairah (1/418) No. (597), No. (596), (595).
3. Narrated by Muslim from Abu Hurairah (1/416) No. (595).
4. Narrated by Muslim from Ka'b bin Ujrah (1/418) No. (596).
5. Narrated by Al-Nasa'i from Zaid bin Thabit (3/76) No. (1350). Al-Albani said: (Authentic) Mishkat al-Masabih (1/307) No. (973).

book_title: Remembrances of Prayers: Before and After
text: Third Formula: "Glorify Allah (*Tasbih*) ten times, Praise Allah (*Tahmid*) ten times, and declare His Greatness (*Takbir*) ten times" (1). The Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, said regarding the virtue of this remembrance: "Two qualities, or two characteristics, no Muslim servant maintains them but he will enter Paradise. They are easy, but those who act upon them are few: He glorifies Allah at the end of every prayer ten times, praises Him ten times, and declares His greatness ten times. That is one hundred and fifty on the tongue, and one thousand five hundred in the Scale..." (2). Note: The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, used to count the Tasbih with his right hand (3).
foot_note:
1. Narrated by Abu Dawud from Abdullah bin Amr (4/316) No. (5065). Al-Albani said: (Authentic) Mishkat al-Masabih: (2/743) No. (2406). The rest of the Hadith: "And he declares Allah's greatness thirty-four times when he takes his bed, praises Him thirty-three times, and glorifies Him thirty-three times. That is one hundred on the tongue, and one thousand in the Scale." I saw the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, counting them with his hand. They said: "O Messenger of Allah, how are they easy and those who act upon them are few?" He said: "Someone comes to one of you—meaning Satan—in his sleep and puts him to sleep before he says it, and comes to him in his prayer and reminds him of a need before he says it."
2. Previous reference.
3. Narrated by Abu Dawud (2/81) No. (1502), Al-Bayhaqi in Al-Sunan Al-Kubra (2/267) No. (3027) from Abdullah bin Amr, who said: "I saw the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, counting the Tasbih." Ibn Qudamah said: "With his right hand." And in Al-Nasa'i: "I saw the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, counting the Tasbih with his right hand." Al-Albani said: (Authentic) Sahih Abi Dawud (5/237) No. (1346).

book_title: Remembrances of Prayers: Before and After
text: Tenth Remembrance: "O Allah, I seek refuge in You from cowardice, and I seek refuge in You from being returned to the most decrepit old age, and I seek refuge in You from the trial of the world, and I seek refuge in You from the punishment of the grave" (1). Eleventh Remembrance: "My Lord, protect me from Your punishment on the Day You resurrect - or gather - Your servants" (2). Twelfth Remembrance: "Glory be to You, O Allah, and with Your praise; there is no god but You. I seek forgiveness from Allah and repent to Him" (3). The Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, explained the virtue of this remembrance by saying:
foot_note:
1. Narrated by Al-Bukhari from Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas (4/23) No. (2822).
2. Narrated by Muslim from Al-Bara' (1/492) No. (709).
3. Narrated by Ahmad from Aisha (41/34) No. (24486), Al-Nasa'i (3/71) No. (1344), containing: "That the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, if he sat in a gathering or prayed, he would speak certain words. Aisha asked him about the words... so he mentioned it." Al-Albani said: (Authentic) Al-Silsilah Al-Sahihah (7/493) No. (3164), and Al-Wadi'i authenticated it in Al-Sahih Al-Musnad No. (1598).

book_title: Remembrances of Prayers: Before and After
text: "If he speaks good, it will be a seal (1) upon them until the Day of Resurrection, and if he speaks other than that, it will be an expiation [for him]." Therefore, it is the last thing to be said. Note: After the written prayers are among the times when supplication is answered (2). Adhkar for Sitting in the Mosque After Prayer: One remembers Allah Almighty with all types of remembrance. However, if he stays in the mosque after the Fajr prayer, it is recommended that he says the Morning Adhkar (known as the Adhkar of the Morning and Evening) and continues remembering Allah Almighty until the sun rises, then prays two Rak'ahs. The Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, said regarding the virtue of the reward of one who sits in the mosque after the Fajr and Asr prayers and remembers Allah Almighty: "Whoever prays
foot_note:
1. (A seal): Meaning, Ibn Hajar said: A stamp upon it until the Day of Resurrection, (Fath Al-Bari) (13/546). Al-Sindi said: A seal that preserves it from loss (Hashiyah Musnad Ahmad, Al-Risala Edition) (41/35).
2. Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi from Abu Umamah (5/526) No. (3499). He said: It was said, O Messenger of Allah: Which supplication is most heard? He said: "In the last part of the night, and at the end of the written prayers." Al-Tirmidhi said: This Hadith is Hasan. Al-Albani said: (Hasan) Mishkat al-Masabih (1/305) No. (968).

book_title: Remembrances of Prayers: Before and After
text: Fajr in congregation, then sits remembering Allah until the sun rises, then prays two Rak'ahs, it will be for him like the reward of a Hajj and an Umrah... complete, complete, complete" (1). He also said: "That I sit with people remembering Allah Almighty from the Morning Prayer until the sun rises is more beloved to me than freeing four of the children of Isma'il. And that I sit with people remembering Allah from the Asr prayer until the sun sets is more beloved to me than freeing four" (2). And he, peace and blessings be upon him, said regarding one who sits in the mosque remembering Allah Almighty: "No people sit remembering Allah Almighty except that the angels surround them, mercy covers them, tranquility descends upon them, and Allah mentions them to those who are with Him." In another narration: "And no people gather in one of the houses of Allah, reciting the Book of Allah and studying it among themselves, except that
foot_note:
1. Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi from Anas (2/481) No. (586). Al-Albani said: (Authentic) Sahih Al-Jami' Al-Saghir (2/1086) No. (6346), and Sahih Al-Targhib No. (464).
2. Narrated by Abu Dawud (3/324) No. (3667). Al-Albani said: (Hasan) Sahih Al-Jami' Al-Saghir (2/899) No. (5036), Silsilat Al-Ahadith Al-Sahihah (6/994) No. (2916).

book_title: Remembrances of Prayers: Before and After
text: tranquility descends upon them, mercy covers them, the angels surround them, and Allah mentions them to those who are with Him" (1). He also said: "When he enters the mosque, he is in prayer as long as the prayer is what detains him, and the angels pray for one of you as long as he is in his sitting place in which he prayed, saying: 'O Allah, have mercy on him; O Allah, forgive him; O Allah, accept his repentance,' as long as he does not harm anyone therein, and as long as he does not break his wudu therein" (2). Remembrance upon Sneezing: If someone sneezes, let him say: "Praise be to Allah" (*Alhamdulillah*). It is said to him: "May Allah have mercy on you" (*Yarhamukallah*). And he must reply by saying: "May Allah guide you and set your condition right" (*Yahdikumullah wa yuslihu balakum*) (3). Remembrance upon Leaving the Mosque: First: "O Allah, I ask You from Your bounty" (4).
foot_note:
1. Narrated by Muslim from Abu Hurairah and Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri (4/2074) No. (2700).
2. Agreed upon: Al-Bukhari (1/132) No. (659), Muslim from Abu Hurairah (1/459) No. (649).
3. Agreed upon: Al-Bukhari from Abu Hurairah (8/49) No. (6224), Muslim (4/2292) No. (2993).
4. Previously cited, under the mention of entering the mosque.

book_title: Remembrances of Prayers: Before and After
text: It came outside the Two Sahihs with the wording: "In the name of Allah, and peace be upon the Messenger of Allah. O Allah, forgive me my sins and open for me the doors of Your bounty. O Allah, protect me—and in a narration (guard me)—from the accursed Satan" (1). Second: "In the name of Allah; O Allah, send prayers upon Muhammad" (2). Remembrance upon seeing an afflicted person: "Praise be to Allah who has spared me from what He has afflicted you with, and favored me over many of those He has created with a distinct favor." The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said whoever says this supplication: "That affliction will not strike him" (3).
foot_note:
1. Narrated by Ibn Majah from Abu Hurairah (1/254) No. (773), Ibn Hibban (5/399) No. (2050), Ahmad (44/13) No. (26416), and Al-Hakim (1/325), with the addition of the word (and prayer) before peace in Al-Hakim and Ahmad, and Al-Hakim authenticated it. 2. Narrated by Ibn Al-Sunni in 'Amal Al-Yawm wa Al-Laylah, from Anas bin Malik (p. 80) No. (88). Al-Albani said: (Hasan) Takhrij Al-Kalim Al-Tayyib (p. 91) No. (64), Al-Thamar Al-Mustatab (2/604).

book_title: Remembrances of Prayers: Before and After
text: Remembrance when passing through the Market: "There is no god but Allah alone, having no partner. To Him belongs the dominion and to Him belongs the praise. He brings to life and causes death, and He is Living and does not die. In His Hand is the good, and He is over all things competent." Regarding the reward of one who says this remembrance, it is stated: "Allah writes for him a million good deeds, wipes away from him a million bad deeds, raises him a million degrees, and builds for him a house in Paradise" (1). Remembrance upon entering the Home: One mentions Allah Almighty when entering his home, such as saying: "In the name of Allah" (*Bismillah*), or saying: "There is no god but Allah," or other phrases termed as remembrance of Allah. Then he greets his family, meaning he says: "Peace be upon you, and the mercy of Allah and His blessings" (*As-salamu 'alaykum wa rahmatullah wa barakatuhu*).
foot_note: 1. Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi from Umar bin Al-Khattab (5/491) No. (3429), Al-Hakim (1/721) No. (1974). Hadith scholars differed regarding this Hadith; some classified it as Hasan, and some weakened it. Whoever agrees with the classification of Hasan may say it. Al-Albani said: (Hasan) Sahih Al-Jami' Al-Saghir and its addition (2/1070) No. (6231), Al-Kalim Al-Tayyib (230), Al-Targhib (3/5).

book_title: Remembrances of Prayers: Before and After
text: Therefore, it is reported in the Hadith of Jabir, may Allah be pleased with him, that he heard the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, say: "When a man enters his house and mentions Allah upon his entry and upon his food, Satan says: 'You have no place to spend the night and no dinner.' But if he enters and does not mention Allah upon his entry, Satan says: 'You have found a place to spend the night.' And if he does not mention Allah upon his food, he says: 'You have found a place to spend the night and dinner'" (1). As for the greeting of peace (Salam), its legitimacy is well-known. Remembrance before eating food or drinking: "In the name of Allah" (*Bismillah*). If he forgets at the beginning, let him say: "In the name of Allah at its beginning and its end" (2). Adhkar after finishing food or drink: First Remembrance: "Praise be to Allah, [a praise] abundant, good, and blessed, insufficient [for His right], not leaving Him (i.e., not a farewell), and indispensable (3), our Lord" (4).
foot_note:
1. Narrated by Muslim from Jabir bin Abdullah (3/1598) No. (2018).
2. Narrated by Al-Tirmidhi from Aisha (4/288) No. (1858) and the wording is his, Abu Dawud (3/347) No. (3767). Al-Albani said: (Authentic) Sahih Al-Jami' Al-Saghir (1/282) No. (1323), Al-Kalim Al-Tayyib No. (183), Al-Irwa No. (1965).
3. (Ghayra makfiy): Meaning what we ate is not sufficient to replace what comes after it; rather, Your blessings are continuous upon us, uninterrupted throughout our lives. (Wa la muwadda'): From bidding farewell, meaning this is not our last food. [Commentary by Mustafa Al-Bugha] in Al-Bukhari.
4. Narrated by Al-Bukhari from Abu Umamah (7/82) No. (5458). The text between brackets is in Abu Dawud (3/366) No. (3849).

book_title: Remembrances of Prayers: Before and After
text: Second Remembrance: "Praise be to Allah who sufficed us and quenched our thirst, neither being insufficient nor denied (1)" (2). Third Remembrance: "Praise be to Allah who fed, gave drink, made it easy to swallow, and made a way out for it" (3). Fourth Remembrance: "Praise be to Allah who fed me this food and provided it to me without any power or strength from me" (4). The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, said regarding the reward of one who says this remembrance: "His past sins will be forgiven."
foot_note:
1. (Wa la makfur): His bounty is not denied nor is His blessing rejected. [Commentary by Mustafa Al-Bugha] in Al-Bukhari.
2. Narrated by Al-Bukhari from Abu Umamah (7/82) No. (5459).
3. Narrated by Abu Dawud from Abu Ayyub Al-Ansari (3/366) No. (3851). Al-Albani said: (Authentic) Sahih Al-Jami' Al-Saghir (2/856) No. (4681), Al-Silsilah Al-Sahihah No. (2061), and it is in Al-Sahih Al-Musnad by Al-Wadi'i No. (318).
4. Narrated by Abu Dawud from Sahl bin Mu'adh bin Anas (4/42) No. (4023). Al-Albani said: (Hasan) Sahih Al-Jami' Al-Saghir: (2/1050) No. (6086), Al-Kalim Al-Tayyib No. (188), Al-Irwa No. (1989).

book_title: Remembrances of Prayers: Before and After
text: The Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, explained the virtue of the one who praises Allah Almighty for food and drink by saying: "Indeed, Allah is pleased with the servant who eats a meal and praises Him for it, or drinks a drink and praises Him for it" (1). Remembrance upon putting aside (i.e., taking off) clothes: "In the name of Allah" (*Bismillah*) (2).
foot_note:
1. Narrated by Muslim from Anas bin Malik (4/2095) No. (2734).
2. Narrated by Al-Tabarani from Anas (3/67) No. (2504). Al-Albani said: (Authentic) Sahih Al-Jami' Al-Saghir and its addition (1/675) No. (3610) with the wording: "The screen between the eyes of the Jinn and the private parts of the children of Adam when one of them puts aside his garment is to say: Bismillah."

book_title: Remembrances of Prayers: Before and After
text: • Section Four: Adhkar Reported in Prayers Other Than the Five Daily Prayers. This includes Adhkar of the Night Prayer, Funeral Prayer, Eid Prayer, Istikhara Prayer, Istisqa Prayer, and Eclipse Prayer. First: Adhkar Reported in the Night Prayer: Adhkar after the Opening Takbir (Takbirat al-Ihram) if he starts the Night Prayer: First Remembrance: "O Allah, to You belongs the praise. You are the Sustainer (1) of the heavens and the earth and whoever is in them. And to You belongs the praise. To You belongs the dominion of the heavens and the earth and whoever is in them. And to You belongs the praise. You are the Light of the heavens and the earth and whoever is in them. And to You belongs the praise. You are the King of the heavens and the earth. And to You belongs the praise. You are the Truth, Your promise is
foot_note: 1. (Qayyim): The One who constantly manages the creation, giving them what sustains their affairs. (And for You I have disputed): For Your sake, I have disputed with the stubborn and the disbeliever and suppressed him with what You have given me of power with the sword and proof. (To You I have submitted for judgment): I have made Your law the judge between me and whoever denies the truth or with whom a dispute arises. [Commentary by Al-Bugha] on Al-Bukhari (2/49).

book_title: Remembrances of Prayers: Before and After
text: the truth, the meeting with You is true, Your word is true, Paradise is true, the Fire is true, the Prophets are true, Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him, is true, and the Hour is true. O Allah, to You I have submitted, in You I have believed, upon You I have relied, to You I have turned, for You I have disputed, and to You I have submitted for judgment. So forgive me what I have sent forward and what I have left behind, what I have concealed and what I have declared. You are the Advancer and You are the Delayer. There is no god but You, and there is no power and no strength except by Allah" (1). Second Remembrance: "O Allah, Lord of Jibril, Mika'il, and Israfil, Originator of the heavens and the earth, Knower of the unseen and the seen, You judge between Your servants concerning that in which they used to differ. Guide me to what has been differed over of the truth by Your permission; indeed, You guide whom You will to a straight path" (2).
foot_note:
1. Agreed upon: Al-Bukhari from Ibn Abbas (2/48) No. (1120), Muslim (1/532) No. (769).
2. Narrated by Muslim from Aisha (1/534) No. (770).

book_title: Remembrances of Prayers: Before and After
text: Third Remembrance: "He says 'Allahu Akbar' ten times, 'Subhan Allah' ten times, 'La ilaha illa Allah' ten times, and seeks forgiveness ten times. He says: 'O Allah, forgive me, guide me, provide for me, [and heal me]' ten times. And he says: 'O Allah, I seek refuge in You from the distress of the Day of Account' ten times" (1). Fourth Remembrance: "Allah is the Greatest [three times], Possessor of Sovereignty, Power, Grandeur, and Greatness" (2). Fifth Remembrance: See the third remembrance of the previously mentioned Opening Adhkar. Remembrance upon reciting the Quran after Al-Fatihah in the Night Prayer: "If he passes by a verse containing glorification, he glorifies; if he passes by a question (request), he asks; and if he passes by seeking refuge, he seeks refuge" (3). This is prescribed for the Imam and the one praying alone, but not for the follower (behind an Imam) because it has not been proven in his case.
foot_note:
1. Narrated by Ahmad from Aisha (42/37, 38) No. (25102), Al-Nasa'i (8/284) No. (5535). The text between brackets is in Al-Nasa'i. Al-Albani said: (Authentic) Sahih Abi Dawud (3/352) No. (742), Sifat Salat al-Nabi (p. 94).
2. Narrated by Abu Dawud from Hudhayfah (1/231) No. (874), and Ahmad (38/392) No. (23375). Al-Albani said: (Authentic) Sahih Abi Dawud (4/27) No. (818), Sifat Salat al-Nabi (p. 94). The text between brackets is in Abu Dawud.
3. Narrated by Muslim from Hudhayfah (1/536) No. (772), Ahmad (38/387) No. (23367).

book_title: Remembrances of Prayers: Before and After
text: Remembrance at the Prostration of Recitation (Sujood Tilawah): He says what he says in the Adhkar of prostration in the written prayers. Remembrance upon rising from bowing (Ruku') in the Night Prayer: He says what we mentioned previously of the Adhkar of rising from Ruku', and he may say: "To my Lord belongs the praise, to my Lord belongs the praise" (1). Remembrance in the Qunut of Witr: "O Allah, guide me among those You have guided, heal me among those You have healed, befriend me among those You have befriended, bless me in what You have given, and protect me from the evil of what You have decreed. For indeed You decree and none decrees against You; and indeed he is not humiliated whom You have befriended, nor is he honored whom You have opposed. Blessed are You, our Lord, and Exalted" (2).
foot_note:
1. Narrated by Al-Nasa'i from Hudhayfah (2/199) No. (1069), Ahmad (38/392) No. (23375). Al-Albani said: (Authentic) Al-Irwa: (335), Sifat Salat al-Nabi: p. (137).
2. Narrated by Abu Dawud from Al-Hasan bin Ali (2/63) No. (1425). Al-Albani said: (Authentic) Sahih Abi Dawud (5/168) No. (1281), Al-Ta'liqat Al-Hisan (2/280) No. (941), and it is in Al-Sahih Al-Musnad by Al-Wadi'i No. (308).

book_title: Remembrances of Prayers: Before and After
text: And if he wishes, he adds this remembrance: "O Allah, I seek refuge in Your pleasure from Your anger, in Your forgiveness from Your punishment, and I seek refuge in You from You. I cannot enumerate praise upon You; You are as You have praised Yourself" (1). Remembrance after the Tasleem of the Witr Prayer: "Glory be to the King, the Holy" (*Subhan al-Malik al-Quddus*) (2) three times, raising his voice on the third time. Benefit: Some of what the Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, used to recite of the Quran in certain prayers: Witr Prayer: The Messenger, peace and blessings be upon him, used to recite in the first Rak'ah Surah Al-A'la: {Glorify the Name of your Lord, the Most High...}, and in the second Rak'ah Surah Al-Kafirun: {Say, O you
foot_note:
1. Narrated by Abu Dawud from Ali bin Abi Talib (2/64) No. (1427). Al-Albani said: (Authentic) Sahih Abi Dawud (5/169) No. (1282), Sahih Al-Jami' Al-Saghir (1/275) No. (1280).
2. Narrated by Abu Dawud from Ubayy bin Ka'b (2/65) No. (1430), Al-Nasa'i (3/244) No. (1732). Al-Albani said: (Authentic) Sahih Abi Dawud (5/173) No. (1284), Al-Ta'liqat Al-Hisan (4/194) No. (2441).

book_title: Remembrances of Prayers: Before and After
text: disbelievers...}, and in the third Rak'ah Surah Al-Ikhlas: {Say, He is Allah, One...} (1). Sunnah of Fajr: He used to recite in the first Rak'ah Surah Al-Kafirun, and in the second Rak'ah Surah Al-Ikhlas (2). Sometimes he would recite in the first Rak'ah: {Say, "We have believed in Allah and what has been revealed to us and what has been revealed to Abraham and Ishmael and Isaac and Jacob and the Descendants and what was given to Moses and Jesus and what was given to the prophets from their Lord. We make no distinction between any of them, and we are Muslims [in submission] to Him."} [Al-Baqarah: (136)].
foot_note:
1. Narrated by Al-Hakim and he authenticated it, and Al-Dhahabi agreed, from Aisha (2/566) No. (3920), Sahih Ibn Hibban (6/188) No. (2432), Al-Nasa'i (3/235) No. (1701), Ahmad (43/79) No. (25906). The Hadith includes the addition of reading the two Mu'awwidhat in the third Rak'ah. The investigator of Musnad Imam Ahmad, Al-Risala edition, said: Hadith (Authentic due to supporting evidence) without the recitation of the Mu'awwidhat, but Al-Albani authenticated it with the recitation of the Mu'awwidhat. See: Al-Ta'liqat Al-Hisan (4/193) No. (2439), Asl Sifat Salat al-Nabi (2/541).
2. Narrated by Muslim from Abu Hurairah (1/502) No. (726).

book_title: Remembrances of Prayers: Before and After
text: And in the second: {But when Jesus felt [persistence in] disbelief from them, he said, "Who are my supporters for [the cause of] Allah?" The disciples said, "We are supporters for Allah. We have believed in Allah and testify that we are Muslims."} [Ali 'Imran: (52)] Or he would recite instead: {Say, "O People of the Scripture, come to a word that is equitable between us and you - that we will not worship except Allah and not associate anything with Him and not take one another as lords instead of Allah." But if they turn away, then say, "Bear witness that we are Muslims."} [Ali 'Imran: (64)] (1). Friday and Eid Prayers: He used to recite in the first Rak'ah Surah Al-A'la, and in the second Rak'ah Surah Al-Ghashiyah (2) {: Has there come to you the report of the Overwhelming Event?}. Sometimes in Friday prayer, he would recite in the first Rak'ah Surah Al-Jumu'ah: {Whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on the earth is exalting Allah, the Sovereign, the Pure, the Exalted in Might, the Wise}, and Surah Al-Munafiqun: {When the hypocrites come to you, they say, "We testify that you are the Messenger of Allah"} in the second Rak'ah (3).
foot_note:
1. Narrated by Muslim from Ibn Abbas (1/502) No. (727).
2. Narrated by Muslim from An-Nu'man bin Bashir (2/598) No. (878).
3. Narrated by Muslim from Abu Hurairah (2/597) No. (877).

book_title: Remembrances of Prayers: Before and After
text: Second: Adhkar Reported in the Funeral Prayer (Janazah): As for the Funeral Prayer, it is known that there is no bowing or prostration in it; rather, it consists of four Takbirs (1). After each Takbir, there is a specific remembrance, as follows: Remembrance after the First Takbir: He reads the Opening of the Book (Al-Fatihah) (2), which is: {Praise be to Allah, Lord of the worlds...}. Remembrance after the Second Takbir: He sends prayers upon Muhammad, peace and blessings be upon him (3). It has formulas previously mentioned in the Adhkar of the final Tashahhud. We mention one here: "O Allah, send prayers upon Muhammad and upon the family of Muhammad, as You sent prayers upon Ibrahim and upon the family of Ibrahim; You are indeed Worthy of Praise, Full of Glory. O Allah, bless
foot_note:

text: Muhammad and upon the family of Muhammad, as You blessed Ibrahim and upon the family of Ibrahim; You are indeed Worthy of Praise, Full of Glory" (1). Exchange for him a home better than his home, a family better than his family, and a spouse better than his spouse. Admit him into Paradise and protect him from the punishment of the grave or from the punishment of the Fire" (2). Second Supplication: "O Allah, forgive our living and our dead, our young and our old, our male and our female, our present and our absent. O Allah, whoever You keep alive among us, keep him alive on Faith,

text: and whoever You cause to die among us, cause him to die on Islam. O Allah, do not deprive us of his reward, and do not lead us astray after him" (1). You are the Possessor of faithfulness and praise. O Allah, forgive him and have mercy on him; indeed, You are the Forgiving, the Merciful" (2). text: Remembrance after the Fourth Takbir: "Peace be upon you and the mercy of Allah," to his right and to his left (1). If he greets once to his right, that is permissible for him (2). Note: If someone prays the Funeral Prayer after an Imam and says five Takbirs, he may recite after the fourth Takbir one of the supplications we mentioned after the third Takbir, for it is part of the prescribed supplication in the Funeral Prayer. Benefit: If the deceased is a child, he says in the prayer for him: "O Allah, make him for us a forerunner (3), a predecessor, and a reward" (4).

text: Benefit: Scholars have mentioned that the Opening Supplication (Istiftaah) is not recommended in the Funeral Prayer, but seeking refuge in Allah from the accursed Satan is said before reciting Al-Fatihah (1). Third: Adhkar Reported in the Two Eid Prayers: Remembrance before reciting Al-Fatihah in the Eid Prayers: He says seven Takbirs in the first Rak'ah, after the Opening Supplication and before reading Al-Fatihah (2), and five Takbirs in the second Rak'ah (3) after standing up from prostration and before the recitation, saying: "Allahu Akbar."

book_title: Remembrances of Prayers: Before and After
text: Benefit: The Eid prayers do not differ from the written prayers or the confirmed Sunnah prayers in their Adhkar except for the mention of the Takbirs and what is reported regarding recitation after Al-Fatihah. And Allah knows best. Note: No remembrance has been reported from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, between the Takbirs in the Eid prayer; rather, he would pause briefly and then say the next Takbir. Fourth: Remembrance Reported in the Istikhara Prayer: "O Allah, I ask You for the good by Your knowledge, and I ask You for strength by Your power, and I ask You from Your great bounty. For indeed You are capable and I am not, You know and I do not know, and You are the Knower of the unseen. O Allah, if You know that this matter is good for me in my religion, my livelihood, and the outcome of my affair - or he said: in my immediate and future affair - then decree it for me. And if You know that this matter is bad for me in my religion, my livelihood, and the outcome of

text: Fourth: "O Allah, give us rain that is relieving, wholesome, fertile (1), beneficial not harmful, sooner not later" (2). Fifth: "O Allah, give us rain that is wholesome, fertile, encompassing, immediate without delay (3), beneficial not harmful" (4). Sixth: "Praise be to Allah, Lord of the worlds, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful, Master of the Day of Judgment. There is no god but Allah; He does what He intends. O Allah, You are Allah, there is no god but You. You are the Rich (Free of need) and we are the poor. Send down rain upon us, and make what You send down for us strength and sufficiency
foot_note:

text: for a time" (1). These remembrances were reported in the sermon for seeking rain. Sixth: Adhkar upon the Eclipse Prayer (Kusuf): Its description is: Two Rak'ahs, with two bowing in each Rak'ah (2). The Muslim must hasten to the remembrance of Allah Almighty: "So he glorifies, praises, declares oneness, and declares greatness," and he likewise hastens to supplication, seeking forgiveness, giving charity, and seeking refuge from the punishment of the grave (3). All of this was reported from the action of the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, and his saying to the Companions.

Agreed upon: Al-Bukhari (2/38) No. (1056), No. (1058), and No. (1059), Muslim (2/628) No. (912) and No. (913) from Abu Musa, who said: The sun eclipsed, so the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, stood up in fright, fearing it was the Hour. He came to the mosque and prayed with the longest standing, bowing, and prostration I had ever seen him do. He said: "These signs that Allah sends are not for the death of anyone nor for his life, but Allah frightens His servants with them. So if you see anything of that, hasten to His remembrance, supplication, and forgiveness." And in Muslim from the Hadith of Abd al-Rahman bin Samura: I said: By Allah, I will watch what happened to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, in the solar eclipse. He said: "I came to him while he was standing in prayer raising his hands, glorifying, praising, declaring oneness, declaring greatness, and supplicating until it cleared." He said: "When it cleared, he recited two Surahs and prayed two Rak'ahs."

book_title: Remembrances of Prayers: Before and After
text: Benefit: It is recommended for the servant, before supplicating, to start by glorifying his Lord Almighty and praising Him, then sending prayers upon the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, then supplicating afterwards with whatever he wills (1). Closing Benefit: The scholar Ibn Uthaymeen mentioned that if acts of worship are reported in varied forms, including the supplications and remembrances of prayers, there are five benefits in that: First Benefit: Performing the Sunnah in all its facets. Second Benefit: Preserving the Sunnah, because if one of the forms is neglected, it might be forgotten and not preserved.
foot_note: 1. Narrated by Abu Dawud (2/77) No. (1481), Ibn Khuzaymah (1/351) No. (710). Al-Albani said: (Authentic), Sahih Abi Dawud (5/221) No. (1331). Its wording: From Fadalah bin Ubayd who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, heard a man supplicating in his prayer without glorifying Allah Almighty and without praying upon the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "This one was hasty." Then he called him and said to him - or to someone else - "When one of you prays, let him start by glorifying his Lord Almighty and praising Him, then pray upon the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, then supplicate afterwards with whatever he wills."

book_title: Remembrances of Prayers: Before and After
text: Third Benefit: Presence of mind regarding what one says of remembrance; for if a person persists on a single remembrance, he begins to say it without his heart being present. But if he deliberately intends to vary them, he achieves presence of heart. Fourth Benefit: A person might choose the easier and simpler one for some reason, thus facilitating matters for himself. Fifth Benefit: Each type contains what isn't in the other, so there is increased praise of Allah Almighty in that (1). Alert: I did not mention the Adhkar of the Tasbih Prayer because most scholars hold the view that what was reported concerning it is not authentic.
